paragraphs.content: A direct object is the person or thing that the verb directly impacts on: Invito Elena (I’m inviting Elena); Uso il computer tutti i giorni (I use the computer every day).

A direct object pronoun replaces a noun used as a direct object; it must therefore agree in gender and number with the noun it refers to. Direct object pronouns normally come before the verb. In the following examples, the pronouns are in italics:

rows: Quando vedo *Elena* *la* invito a cena. [la replaces and agrees with Elena (fs)]
When I see Elena I’ll invite *her* to dinner.
Quando vedo *Lorenzo* *lo* invito a cena. [lo replaces and agrees with Lorenzo (ms)]
When I see Lorenzo I’ll invite *him* to dinner.
Scrivo *le cartoline* e poi *le* imbuco. [le replaces and agrees with le cartoline (fp)]
I write the postcards and then post *them*.
Appena compro *i biscotti* *li* mangio. [li replaces and agrees with i biscotti (mp)]
As soon as I buy biscuits I eat *them*.
Prendo *il giornale* e *lo* leggo subito. [lo replaces and agrees with il giornale (ms)]
I get the paper and read *it* immediately.

paragraphs.content: The forms of the direct object pronouns are as follows:

We saw in Unit 3 that if an adjective refers to two or more nouns that are different in gender, it has the masculine plural form, e.g. Laura e Piero sono italiani (Laura and Piero are Italian). The same principle applies to direct object pronouns:

rows: ‘Do you know Laura and Piero?’ ‘Yes, I know *them* well.’
‘Usi *il computer [m] e la stampante [f]*?’ ‘Sì, *li [mp]* uso spesso.’
‘Do you use the computer and the printer?’ ‘Yes, I often use *them*.’

paragraphs.content: The negative is formed by putting non before the pronoun:

rows: I’m not inviting *you* to the party.

Each pair of sentences has exactly the same meaning – the form used makes no difference.
* Note that verbs in -urre drop the second r as well as the final vowel: lo devo tradurre or devo tradurlo.

sections.title: Using Lo to Replace a Clause

paragraphs.content: The pronoun lo [ms] is often used to replace a whole clause:

rows: ‘Sai che oggi è il compleanno di Carla?’ ‘Sì, *lo* so.’ [lo = oggi è il compleanno di Carla]
‘Do you know that it’s Carla’s birthday today?’ ‘Yes, I do.’ [lit. Yes, I know *it*]
‘Dove sono le chiavi?’ ‘Non *lo* so.’ [lo = dove sono le chiavi]
‘Where are the keys?’ ‘I don’t know.’ [lit. I don’t know *it*]
‘Devi cambiare la cartuccia.’ ‘*Lo* faccio subito.’ [lo = cambiare la cartuccia]
‘You’ve got to replace the cartridge.’ ‘I’ll do *it* straight away.’

paragraphs.content: When the pronouns lo and la are used with the verb avere, they are shortened to l’, and are often preceded by the particle ce:

rows: ‘Have you got the cartridge?’ ‘Yes, I’ve got *it*.’
Non posso leggere *il libro di Primo Levi* perché *non ce l’ho*.
I can’t read Primo Levi’s book because I haven’t got *it*.
‘Have you got Anna’s address?’ ‘Yes, we have/Yes, we’ve got *it*.’

paragraphs.content: The plural pronouns li and le, however, are never shortened, and are only rarely used with ce:

rows: ‘Hai *le parole di questa canzone*?’ ‘No, *non (ce) le ho*.’
‘Have you got the lyrics of this song?’ ‘No, I haven’t /No, I’ve not got *them*.’
‘Have you got the books?’ ‘Yes, I’ve got *them*/Yes, I have.’

paragraphs.content: The direct object pronouns used for the formal form are La for the singular (for both women and men) and Vi for the plural (the pronouns Li and Le can also be used for the masculine and feminine respectively, but this is particularly formal):

rows: Professor Masi, I’ll take *you* to the airport.
I’ll take *you* to the airport, Madam.
Mr and Mrs Bianco, I’ll take *you* to the airport.
Mr and Mrs Bianco, I’ll take *you* to the airport.
Signore, *Vi* accompagno in aeroporto. (Signore, *Le* accompagno in aeroporto.)

exercises.title: Exercise 5: Translate into Italian
exercises.instruction: Translate the following sentences into Italian.
examples: We’re inviting *you [pl.]* to the party: *Vi* invitiamo alla festa.
I’ve got a lot of friends, and I often see *them*: Ho *molti amici* e *li* vedo spesso.

items.question: I’ve got a lot of friends, and I often see *them*.
items.answer: Ho molti amici e li vedo spesso.

items.question: Signora Fusi, can I call *you* tomorrow?
items.answer: Signora Fusi, La posso chiamare domani?

items.question: Olga and Anna are leaving tomorrow and I want to take *them* to the station.
items.answer: Olga e Anna partono domani e voglio accompagnarle in stazione.

items.question: Tullio buys *these magazines* and reads *them*.
items.answer: Tullio compra queste riviste e le legge.

items.question: Can *you [sing.]* take *me* to school tomorrow?
items.answer: Mi puoi portare a scuola domani?
